page.title: 01The Village of Ravensworth
page.content: {Ravensworth,}situated five miles north west of{Richmond,}is on a slight knoll to the south of the{Holme Beck}in the middle of the wide valley which was formed by the{Teesdale glacier}during the last ice age. The name refers to the{"wath"}or{ford of Raven,}a{Saxon} who was probably the first "Lord of the Manor"and laid the foundations of the present village. It can be found in the{Domesday Book.} There are the remains of a castle (see page 5) to the south of the village,it is triangular in shape.The large{Green}is surrounded by houses on all sides.Most of the buildings were raised in the late{17 cent.}They are {two storey stone buildings}with{red {clay pantile roofs}and natural{stone {slates.}The{stone chimneys}are on the {gable ends}and other features include {gable copings}and{kneelers}.(Cont. P2)
